column1: Pathum Thani (Thai: ปทุมธานี
column2: pronounced [pā.tʰūm tʰāːnīː]) is one of the central provinces (changwat) of Thailand. Neighboring provinces are (from north clockwise): Ayutthaya

column1: The province is north of Bangkok and is part of the Bangkok metropolitan area. In many places the boundary between the two provinces is not noticeable as both sides of the boundary are equally urbanized. Pathum Thani town is the administrative seat
column4: is the largest populated place in the province.Pathum Thani is an old province
column5: heavily populated by the Mon people
column6: dotted with 186 temples and parks. The Dream World amusement park is here.

column1: The province lies on the low alluvial flats of the Chao Phraya River that flows through the capital. Many canals (khlongs) cross the province and feed the rice paddies.

The city dates back to a settlement founded by Mon migrating from Mottama (Thai: เมาะตะมะ) in Myanmar around 1650. The original name was Sam Khok. In 1815 King Rama II visited the city and the citizens offered him many lotus flowers
column2: which prompted the king to rename the city Pathum Thani

column1: The provincial seal shows a pink lotus flower with two rice stalks bending over it
column2: representing the fertility of the province. The provincial tree is the Indian coral tree (Erythrina variegata). The provincial flower is the lotus (Nymphaea lotus).

column1: The province is divided into seven districts (amphoes). The districts are further subdivided into 60 communes (tambons) and 529 villages (mubans).

As of 29 September 2020 there are: one Pathum Thani Provincial Administrative Organization - PAO (ongkan borihan suan changwat) and twenty-nine municipal (thesaban) areas in the province. Rangsit has city (thesaban nakhon) status. Further ten have town (thesaban mueang) status and eightteen subdistrict  municipalities (thesaban tambon).
The non-municipal areas are administered by 36 Subdistrict Administrative Organizations - SAO (ongkan borihan suan tambon).
